text:
Schematic test plan:

Thread Group
-  HTTP Header Manager 1
-  Simple Controller
- -  HTTP Sampler 1
-  Simple Controller
- -  HTTP Header Manager 2
- -  HTTP Sampler 2
- Tree View

I would have expected Sampler 2 to pick up the headers from Header 2, but these
were ignored.

The following test worked as expected:

Thread Group
-  Simple Controller
- -  HTTP Header Manager 1
- -  HTTP Sampler 1
-  Simple Controller
- -  HTTP Header Manager 2
- -  HTTP Sampler 2
- Tree View

The same happens with Cookies.

According to the Usermanual, local config elememts are supposed to override ones
in the parent branch, but this does not appear to be happening.

[I'll investigate this later, just want to record the problem before I forget!]

Note that HTTP Request Defaults do work as documented, i.e. local elements
override parent elements.

TCP Request Defaults seem not to work at all; likewise Java Request defaults
(this also needs to be investigated further).
creator: sebb@apache.org

text:
TCP Request Defaults do work, after all - my mistake.

Inspection of the code shows that the problem with the Cookie Manager etc seems
to be that they don't just store variables in the test element, the Managers are
invoked at run-time. 

Defaults are cumulative, which seems correct, but Cookies etc should be local
only (otherwise impossible to cancel inherited cookies).

The child cookie manager should override any at the sibling level.

But I could not work out how to fix this.
creator: sebb@apache.org
sebb@apache.org
text:
It appears that the HTTPSamplers are passed all the Manager config items in
turn; they save the last one passed in, whatever that happens to be.

It looks to be quite difficult to establish which Manager is the "closest" to
the Sampler (in theory this would be its child), so I've updated the documentation.

Changing status to LATER, in case the precedence issues can be resolved.

For example, it might be useful if one could set up a default manager at the
same  level or higher level than the samplers, but allow individual samplers to
have a different manager at child level.
